The South Korean government is shifting its strategy toward securing nuclear-powered submarines (SSNs) by pursuing a separate agreement with the United States, distinct from the ongoing revision of the existing U.S.-South Korea Atomic Energy Agreement (also known as the '123 Agreement'). The AUKUS agreement, which enabled Australia to receive nuclear submarine technology, was the result of a three-year process involving U.S. legislative changes and congressional ratification. South Korea aims to replicate this approach by emphasizing regional security cooperation in the Indo-Pacific, thereby justifying the transfer of nuclear submarine-related technology without altering the original agreement's peaceful-use framework. The current 123 Agreement allows South Korea to enrich uranium below 20% only with U.S. prior consent and prohibits reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel. Meanwhile, South Korea has reportedly advanced its domestic nuclear submarine program, with the Ministry of National Defense confirming ongoing development of reactor systems, armament, and safety verification. If nuclear fuel is secured, South Korea aims to begin construction in the late 2020s and achieve the launch of its first SSN by the late 2030s.
